update.description:
As part of refactoring [https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2977/add-gz\_profile-and-introspectionmanager/diff](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2977/add-gz_profile-and-introspectionmanager/diff), I have decided to bring the Profiler into the ignition-common library.

This is still a work in progress, but it shows the implementation of using Remotery \([https://github.com/Celtoys/Remotery](https://github.com/Celtoys/Remotery)\) to profile multiple threads and visualize.

Remotery itself does not provide any CMake logic, so I have done so here: [https://github.com/mjcarroll/remotery\_vendor](https://github.com/mjcarroll/remotery_vendor)

Multiple profiler implementations can be created by inheriting from the ProfilerImpl obj.

You can use the Remotery profiler by:

    # In one terminal
    ./build/ignition-common3/bin/UNIT_Profiler_TEST
    # In another terminal (assuming remotery_vendor)
    xdg-open ./install/share/Remotery/vis/index.html
update.title: Create a common Profiler

content.raw:
The closest parallel I can trace is with the doxygen HTML files being installed by `ign-cmake`, which end up in a `share` folder, i.e.:

`/usr/local/share/ignition/ignition-cmake2/doxygen/header.html`

content.raw: Alright, I have vendored the Remotery source in the updated PR.  The only open question is how/where to install the visualization page, which resides in the `Remotery/vis` directory.  I was previously putting it in a `share` folder in the other `remotery_vendor` package.  What would be the best way to do this via ign-cmake?
content.html: Alright, I have vendored the Remotery source in the updated PR. The only open question is how/where to install the visualization page, which resides in the Remotery/vis directory. I was previously putting it in a share folder in the other remotery_vendor package. What would be the best way to do this via ign-cmake?

update.description:
As part of refactoring [https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2977/add-gz\_profile-and-introspectionmanager/diff](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2977/add-gz_profile-and-introspectionmanager/diff), I have decided to bring the Profiler into the ignition-common library.

This is still a work in progress, but it shows the implementation of using Remotery \([https://github.com/Celtoys/Remotery](https://github.com/Celtoys/Remotery)\) to profile multiple threads and visualize.

Remotery itself does not provide any CMake logic, so I have done so here: [https://github.com/mjcarroll/remotery\_vendor](https://github.com/mjcarroll/remotery_vendor)

Multiple profiler implementations can be created by inheriting from the ProfilerImpl obj.

You can use the Remotery profiler by:

    # In one terminal
    ./build/ignition-common3/bin/UNIT_Profiler_TEST
    # In another terminal (assuming remotery_vendor)
    xdg-open ./install/share/Remotery/vis/index.html
update.title: Create a common Profiler

content.raw:
> we could potentially generate a package off of that

We (read @\_jrivero\_) have released 3rd party packages into ubuntu the past, such as Simbody. I'm not sure how much work that is though, and what's the usual involvement of the library's maintainers.

> bring the entire dep into the ignition-common repo

We've also done this in the past, from large dependencies like ODE, to medium ones like GTest, until header-only ones like Tiny OBJ loader. I'd lean towards starting with that, since it should be the path of least resistance. Remotery is Apache2-licensed, so we should be ok.
content.html:
we could potentially generate a package off of that

We (read @_jrivero_) have released 3rd party packages into ubuntu the past, such as Simbody. I'm not sure how much work that is though, and what's the usual involvement of the library's maintainers.

bring the entire dep into the ignition-common repo

We've also done this in the past, from large dependencies like ODE, to medium ones like GTest, until header-only ones like Tiny OBJ loader. I'd lean towards starting with that, since it should be the path of least resistance. Remotery is Apache2-licensed, so we should be ok.

content.raw:
It is currently not in Ubuntu.

For my current work, I created a vendor package: [https://github.com/mjcarroll/remotery\_vendor](https://github.com/mjcarroll/remotery_vendor) that I just clone in my colcon workspace.  Since it’s a static library and headers, we could potentially generate a package off of that.

As you said, the alternative would be to bring the entire dep into the ignition-common repo.  It’s pretty lightweight \(a c file, a header file, and the visualization webpage\).
content.html:
It is currently not in Ubuntu.

For my current work, I created a vendor package: https://github.com/mjcarroll/remotery_vendor that I just clone in my colcon workspace. Since it’s a static library and headers, we could potentially generate a package off of that.

As you said, the alternative would be to bring the entire dep into the ignition-common repo. It’s pretty lightweight (a c file, a header file, and the visualization webpage).

content.raw:
Looks promising! Have you thought about the integration plan?

* Is Remotery in Ubuntu?
* If not, is the idea to embed the dependency, to lead the integration into Ubuntu, to offer it in our package repo \(and make the profiler an optional component\)?
* About the CMake support: Should we create a new FindRemotery.cmake in `Ignition CMake`?
content.html:
Looks promising! Have you thought about the integration plan?

  • Is Remotery in Ubuntu?
  • If not, is the idea to embed the dependency, to lead the integration into Ubuntu, to offer it in our package repo (and make the profiler an optional component)?
  • About the CMake support: Should we create a new FindRemotery.cmake in Ignition CMake?
